Package it.polimi.ingsw.model.weaponry.constraints

Class Constraint

  • java.lang.Object
    • it.polimi.ingsw.model.weaponry.constraints.Constraint
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AlignmentConstraint, DistanceConstraint, IdentityConstraint, OrderConstraint, RoomConstraint, VisibilityConstraint
    public abstract class Constraint
extends java.lang.Object
    A constraint is a simple rule that can be verified or falsified. It is expressed in a form similar to a well-formed formula of the monadic first-order logic. Constraints come in different types, each representing a different predicate. Most predicates expressed by constraints have arity 2, i.e. they describe a situation verifiable on 2 entities, they're also known as binary constraints. All constraints are verified inside an AttackPattern that acts like a context outside of which the predicate is ambiguous and cannot therefore be verified.
    Binary constraints always include:
    • Source: the first actor of the predicate, or the "subject".
    • Drain: the last actor of the predicate, or the "object".
    There are also ternary constraints, that make a statement about three entities, and also include:
    • Gate: the middle actor of the predicate, or the "intermediary".

    When constraints are evaluated, their subjects, objects and/or intermediaries often need to be referenced in a host of different situations, making integers an easy and versatile solution for creating a path of references that leads to the entity of interest for each role in the constraint. Specifically, each entity is reached by:
    • An AttackModule id: used to identify the AttackModule in which the entity resides. This is possible because constraints are limited to one AttackPattern, making it unambiguous which AttackModule the id refers to.
    • A Target id: used to identify the Target inside the AttackModule that refers to the entity of interest, whether it be a Cell, a Room or a Player.
    This indexed access algorithm makes it impossible to reference Targets defined in a future moment with respect to the moment in which a constraint attempts to reference an entity as one of its actors, even within the same AttackModule. In other words, it is impossible to evaluate a constraint depending partially on decisions not yet taken by the player.
    In order to grant the constraints internal language a fully operational expressive power, at least as far as the game logic is concerned, the following encoding rules for numeric ids were devised:
    • Any non-negative integer: simply refers to the index of the AttackModule inside the context, or to the index of the Target inside the AttackModule, as described above.
    • -1: Refers to the attacker (always known from within the context, as an AttackPattern cannot be used until it has been signed by a Player as its author).
    • -2: Refers to the attacker, but in the position they had before the beginning of the current AttackPattern.
    • -3: Refers to anyone, much like the "for all" operator in the monadic first order logic. This value is very important when generating lists of entities that make the constraint evaluate to true: each entity is given the role the -3 is found in, and gets replaced by the following entity for elaborating the truth table. All entities that make the constraint evaluate to true are considered eligible for a choice of the Player, when they'll be presented with a question.

      • build

        public static Constraint build​(DecoratedJsonObject jConstraint)
                        throws InvalidConstraintTypeException
        This factory method instantiates and returns a constraint, with the properties found inside the JSON object passed as argument.
        Parameters:
        jConstraint - the JSON object containing the desired properties.
        Returns:
        an instance of this class in accordance with the specified properties.
        Throws:
        InvalidConstraintTypeException - when attempting to instantiate a new constraint whose type is not in the enumeration of possible PowerUp types.

      • getTarget

        public static Target getTarget​(AttackPattern context,
                               int attackModuleId,
                               int targetId)
        Given an AttackPattern to provide a context, it searches for the Target identified by the AttackModule id inside the context and the Target id inside the module.
        Parameters:
        context - The AttackPattern of reference.
        attackModuleId - The id of the AttackModule inside which to look for the Target.
        targetId - The id of the Target inside the AttackModule.
        Returns:
        the Target.

      • filterPlayers

        public static java.util.List<Player> filterPlayers​(AttackPattern context,
                                                   java.util.List<Constraint> constraints)
        Given an AttackPattern to provide a context, it searches for all Players that meet the requirements expressed by all of the Constraints inside a list.
        Parameters:
        context - The AttackPattern of interest.
        constraints - The list of Constraints.
        Returns:
        all the Players that satisfy every Constraint in the list.
